LTER_EUROPE|03715-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides phytoplankton densities recorded in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were fixed with Lugol's solution. An integrated sample was subsequently obtained by combining equal proportions of samples collected at various depths and phytoplankton were identified and counted with an inverted microscopeaccording to Utermöhl (1958).

LTER_EUROPE|03715-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Ruttner bottle
LTER_EUROPE|03715-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Phytoplankton samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were fixed with Lugol's solution. An integrated sample was subsequently obtained by combining equal proportions of samples collected at various depths. Phytoplankton were identified and counted with an inverted microscope according to Utermöhl (1958). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03719-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides chlorophyll-a concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples for chlorophyll-a analysis were collected by means of a Ruttner Bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed according to Strickland and Parsons (1968).

LTER_EUROPE|03719-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Ruttner bottle
LTER_EUROPE|03719-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory, where chlorophyll-a was determined following the method proposed by Strickland and Parsons (1968). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03721-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/contact/electronicMailAddress|dianamicasm@gmail.com
LTER_EUROPE|03721-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Air quality data represents concentrations of O3, NO2 and NH3 measured during the period 15.05-15.10 (monthly exposure) of years 2011 and 2012 in 11 plots in Bucegi-Piatra Craiului LTER site. The pollutants were monitored using Ogawa passive samplers (www.ogawausa.com). Chemical analysis of passive samplers was performed at ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory, using ion-chromatography for ozone determination and colorimetry for NO2 and NH3.Atmospheric depositions were measured during the whole period (2011-2012) in 6 plots. Precipitations were collected inside the forest (throughfall) using 8 collectors and in open field using 2 collectors. Soil solution was monitored in 2 plots, using the profile method, with collectors placed at 10, 20, 40 and 60 cm depth (2 replicates). The reported parameters are: pH (determined by potentiometry), conductivity (conductimetry), nitrite in NH4 and inNH3 (water ion-chromatography) and alkalinity (titrimetric determination). All chemical analysis were performed by ICAS Campulung Moldovenesc laboratory following the methodology described in ICP Forests Manual (http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_Depo.pdf; http://www.icp-forests.org/pdf/FINAL_SoilSol.pdf)

LTER_EUROPE|03722-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides nitrate concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed by means of the Ultraviolet Spectrophotometric Screening Method (Armstrong, 1963)

LTER_EUROPE|03722-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Armstrong, F.A.J. 1963. Determination of nitrate in water by ultraviolet spectrophotometry. Anal. Chem. 35:1292-1294.
LTER_EUROPE|03722-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Ruttner bottle
LTER_EUROPE|03722-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory where nitrate concentrations were determined by means of the Ultraviolet Spectrophotometric Screening Method (Armstrong, 1963). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03728-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, bottom; Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory where ammonium concentrations were determined spectrophotometrically following the Indophenol blue method (Koroleff, 1970). Sampling was carried out monthly from June to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03733-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Data set contains abiotic parameters of the Zingster Strom water column (upper 50 cm). The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

LTER_EUROPE|03733-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range.
LTER_EUROPE|03733-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|salinity: WTW Cond 1970iwater temperature: mercury thermometerSecchi diskturbidity: Xion 500 photmeter, 5 cm cell lengthpH: Hach-Lange IntelliCell, HQ30doxygen: Hach-Lange LDO optode, HQ30d
LTER_EUROPE|03733-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column daily at 08:00 CET. Oxygen saturation is measured in a Karlsruher bottle within 5 min in the lab. Salinity, turbidity and pH are measured in 15-20°C warm samples. The sampling spot represents a very small spot of the area. However, the Zingster Strom is subject to in- and outflows of the neigbouring bodden basins. This brings a high variability of day-to-day data, but may expand the areal coverage/representation.

LTER_EUROPE|03734-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Precipitation was collected over longer periods (~monthly) using rainfall collectors and bulk samplers. LTER_EUROPE|03734-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Precipitation collectors: 1 above-canopy (25m) and 7 throughfall collector (1.2 m) with 0.2 m2 collecting area. Bulk samplers (25 l). Standard water chemistry analysis methods.
LTER_EUROPE|03734-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Bulk samples were collected 6 times during 2012, covering the vegetation period from May to November. The over-canopy collector was set on the top of the site's own meteorological tower. Below-canopy collectors were randomly distributed in the 'B' subplot (50x50m) of the permanent 1 ha plot of the site. Results of all sampling dates were averaged on the basis of collectors' position (over- or below-canopy).

LTER_EUROPE|03735-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Triplicated water samples fixed with formaldehyde (4% V/V) in situ. Ssp identification with inverted optical microscope with epifluorescence (Olympus IX50). Counting of individual phytoplankton cells after filtering 0.1 ml through black Isopore membrane filters GTBP with a 0.2 μm pore size and washing the cells with citrate buffer (pH 6). Each filter was examined for the autofluorescence of cell pigments at 1000X. The measurements were made under microscope according to the method described by Fry (FRY, J. C. 1990. Direct methods and biomass estimation. Methods in Microbiology, 122: 41–85).
LTER_EUROPE|03735-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Olympus IX50 microscope with epifluorescence
LTER_EUROPE|03735-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Triplicated water samples fixed with formaldehyde (4% V/V) in situ. Ssp identification with inverted optical microscope with epifluorescence (Olympus IX50). Counting of individual phytoplankton cells after filtering 0.1 ml through black Isopore membrane filters GTBP with a 0.2 μm pore size and washing the cells with citrate buffer (pH 6). Each filter was examined for the autofluorescence of cell pigments at 1000X. The measurements were made under microscope according to the method described by Fry (FRY, J. C. 1990. Direct methods and biomass estimation. Methods in Microbiology, 122: 41–85).

LTER_EUROPE|03740-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Data on tree and stand parameters (mean diameter and height of trees, tree density, basal area and tree volume per hectare) as well as crown defoliation were available from the permanent observation stands. A three-stage sampling pattern was used for the collection of the field material: (i)                  sampling of the research stands; (ii)                sampling of the circular plots within each research stand; (iii)         sampling of the trees for more detailed measurements of tree crown parameters and tree ring analysis. Each pine stand included 12 circular sample plots distributed systematically in a grid system with on average 15-20 trees in each plot, i.e.; about 150-250 sample trees per stand. There, tree stem diameter was permanently measured and crown defoliation assessed for all sample trees annually. In addition three closest to the centre of sampling plot trees were sampled for measurement of crown parameters (height, diameter and length) and analysis of annual radial increment (tree ring width). Standard dendrochronological technique was used to assess tree growth rates. Radial growth was assessed by measuring the width of annual rings in stem cores. Each ring was measured to the closest 0.01 mm using an electronic transducer and binocular scope fixed over the moving stage. Based on the ring widths and measured diameter we computed stem basal area increment (BAI). For each of the POS a BAI chronology was computed by averaging the BAI for each year across all trees sampled at POS. Crown defoliation was assessed at the end of August. Forest monitoring methodology was employed to assess tree defoliation: healthy trees – (defoliation up to 10%); slightly damaged trees (defoliation ranging from 11 to 25%); moderately damaged trees (defoliation 26–60%); severely damaged trees (defoliation 61–99%); dead trees (defoliation 100%) (UN-ECE, 1994). 
LTER_EUROPE|03740-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Instrument for tree dendrometric parameters measurement

LTER_EUROPE|03741-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Habitat type was determined according to the Council Directive 92/43/EEC on the Conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora. The site is characterized as unmanaged, since it is protected by law as nature conservation area. Natural disturbances: grazing: visual observation of insect bursts and defoliation. droughts: calculation of monthly De Martonne aridity indices using monthly sum precipitation and monthly mean temperature data as follows: prec/(temp+10)*12. Months with Idx DM lower than 20 (semi arid or dry) were considered as dry periods.
LTER_EUROPE|03741-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Weather data were measured by the site's own meteorological staition at 25m above ground: Hobo ProSeries RHandTemp sensor and Hobo Micro Station with rain gaugue (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA)

LTER_EUROPE|03748-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Data were collected at different type specific sites situated at upper, middle and low part of the Mesta River. Physicochemical data (oxygen concentration, water temperature, pH, conductivity and biogens) were taken during 2012. At that time were collected macrophytes, macrozoobenthos, phytobenthos and fishes samples.

LTER_EUROPE|03749-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03749-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Vertical profiles of underwater photosynthetic active radiation (PAR) are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site.Data are used to characterize the light field and light extinction in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03750-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Italy
LTER_EUROPE|03750-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-05-16
LTER_EUROPE|03750-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03750-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Vertical profiles of temperature are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1), using a CTD multiparametric probe. The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Data are used to characterize the temporal dynamic of hydrological properties in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03757-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Monthly standard meteorological data from Fülöpháza which are representative for the whole KISKUN LTER. The station is operated jointly by Centre for Ecological Research, Hungarian Academy of Sciences and Hungarian Meteorological Service. The measured data: air, ground, soil temperature, precipitation, air humidity, wind speed, soil moisture, atmospheric pressure and global radiation.

LTER_EUROPE|03758-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides chlorophyll-a concentrations measured in Lake Scuro Parmense in 2012. Water samples for chlorophyll-a analysis were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column atthe point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed according to Strickland and Parsons (1968).

LTER_EUROPE|03758-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, bottom; Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory where chlorophyll-a was determined spectrophotometrically following Strickland and Parsons (1968). Sampling was carried out monthly from June to October 2012.

Sampling was carried out monthly from June to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03766-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|20 stands were located in the surroundings of Integrated monitoring stations (IMS) established there, and were selected according to stand maturity: 4 sapling stands (45–50 years), 4 middle aged stands (61–80 years), 4 premature stands (81–100 years), 3 mature stands (101– 120 years) and 5 over mature stands more than121 years). Data on tree and stand parameters (mean diameter and height of trees, tree density, basal area and tree volume per hectare) as well as crown defoliation were available from the permanent observation stands. A three-stage sampling pattern was used for the collection of the field material: (i)                  sampling of the research stands; (ii)                sampling of the circular plots within each research stand; (iii)         sampling of the trees for more detailed measurements of tree crown parameters and tree ring analysis. Each pine stand included 12 circular sample plots distributed systematically in a grid system with on average 15-20 trees in each plot, i.e.; about 150-250 sample trees per stand. There, tree stem diameter was permanently measured and crown defoliation assessed for all sample trees annually. In addition three closest to the centre of sampling plot trees were sampled for measurement of crown parameters (height, diameter and length) and analysis of annual radial increment (tree ring width). Standard dendrochronological technique was used to assess tree growth rates. Radial growth was assessed by measuring the width of annual rings in stem cores. Each ring was measured to the closest 0.01 mm using an electronic transducer and binocular scope fixed over the moving stage. Based on the ring widths and measured diameter we computed stem basal area increment (BAI). For each of the POS a BAI chronology was computed by averaging the BAI for each year across all trees sampled at POS. Crown defoliation was assessed at the end of August. Forest monitoring methodology was employed to assess tree defoliation: healthy trees – (defoliation up to 10%); slightly damaged trees (defoliation ranging from 11 to 25%); moderately damaged trees (defoliation 26–60%); severely damaged trees (defoliation 61–99%); dead trees (defoliation 100%) (UN-ECE, 1994). 
LTER_EUROPE|03766-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Instruments for estimation of the tree dendromentric parameters

LTER_EUROPE|03767-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Weather data were collected on the top of the site's meteorological tower (25 m), above the forest canopy layer. The sampling interval was 10 min. Weather records were aggregated on monthly base. The following weather data were collected: Monthly mean, minimum and maximum air temperatures (2011-2012). Windspeed (2012) Monthly sums of precipitation (2011-2012) Global radiation (2012) PPFD (2011-2012) yearly mean air temperature (2011, 2012) yearly sum of precipitation (2011, 2012) DE Martonne aridity index (2011, 2012) calculated as: Rain/(Temp+10)

LTER_EUROPE|03768-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides dissolved oxygen measured in Lake Scuro Parmense in 2012. Water samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Dissolved oxygen was measured in the lab by means of the Winkler method.

LTER_EUROPE|03768-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, bottom; Winkler reagents were immediately added to samples, which were then kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory for analysis according to the Winkler method. Sampling was carried out monthly from June to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03769-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The dataset is created according to the ICP Forests Ground Vegetation manual. The nomenclature follows the Flora Europaea (Tutin et al., 1968-1980; Tutin et al., 1993) for vascular plants and Frey et al. (1995) for bryophytes.  
LTER_EUROPE|03769-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Procedures for data validation follow the GV manual of ICP Forests. The dataset is already validated by University of Camerino the Responsible Body for data validation.
LTER_EUROPE|03769-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|The sampling units are not contiguous; they are placed as far apart as possible within the Level II plot in order to minimize spatial correlation between the sampling units. All measures of the sampling units are taken according to the slope. To achieve a statistical representativeness, probability sampling methods are adopted (random, systematic, stratification). Location of sampling unit excludes major heterogeneities at any scale of sampling (boulders and cliffs, tracks and paths, fire places, streams and ponds, ditches and channels, peaty pools). Thus, terricolous plants growing on mineral and organic soil of the undisturbed forest floor are represented.
LTER_EUROPE|03769-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription|seasonally

LTER_EUROPE|03770-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Automatically logged volumetric soil water content data from several soil depths.
LTER_EUROPE|03770-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|5TM and EC-5 volumetric water content sensors and automatic dataloggers (Decagon Devices Inc., WA, USA)
LTER_EUROPE|03770-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|3 groups of sensors were set in the 1 ha permanent plot of the LTER site. Sensors were inserted to 4, 15, 30, 45 and 60 cm depths, respectively. The sampling rate ranged between 10 and 30 min. Means of respective sensors were averaged and monthly mean volumetric water contents were calculated in 2011 and 2012.

Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, bottom; Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory where pH was measured with a pH meter. Sampling was carried out monthly from June to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03781-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03781-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03781-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Biomass and LAI in grasslands was measured by harvesting all herbs and plant material over a small parcel of 0.25 m2. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight.From the dried material three fractions were separated: (1) plant material which was dead in the time of clipping, (2) non-photosynthesising living material, and (3) photosynthesising material. Biomass was calculated by summing up the dry weight of all living material, and expressed in grams / m2. For LAI measurement, the photosynthesising material was separated into groups consisting parts of seemingly similar morphology, and therefore specific leaf area (SLA). Then, the groups are weighted, and subsamples of known weights are taken for area measurement, applying high resolution scanner. Calculation of SLA and LAI: The subsamples of known weight and area provide the SLA in m2 / grams for the morphology groups, and the total area of the groups can be calculated by multiplying their SLA and weight. Sum of the areas of the morphology groups divided by the area of sampling unit provides LAI in m2 / m2.
LTER_EUROPE|03781-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03782-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|IT_SI001243_Gulf of Trieste_15052013_Phosphate
LTER_EUROPE|03782-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Italy
LTER_EUROPE|03782-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-05-16
LTER_EUROPE|03782-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03782-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Discrete water samples for phosphate(P-PO4) analysis were collected at 0.5, 5, 10 and 15 meters in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Nitrite is measured colorimetrically after sample pre-filtration, using a segmented flow analyzer. Data are used to study biogeochemical nutrient cycles in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. Availability and partition of nitrogen in dissolved and particulate pools result from the concurrence of different forcing factors such as the general circulation, alternation between summer stratification and winter mixing, weather conditions, river discharge, diffuse and point-source continental inputs, sediment–water interactions and several biological processes. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03783-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Different methods are used according to the parameter measured, temperature  and pH are mesaured during sampling with the autosampler; the other parameters are measured in the laboratory; Conductivity is referred to 20 °C; Total alkalinity determination is done with Gran's method; Dissolved oxygen is measured with Winkler's volumetric method; ; Spectrophotometry is used for Total Phosphorus after autoclave mineralization    
LTER_EUROPE|03783-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Reversing termometer associated with sampling bottle, Conductometer in laboratory, , autosampler (Gran's method),  Titration, pHmeter, Spectrophotometer
LTER_EUROPE|03783-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Measurements are performed at 4 depths (0, 5, 10 and 20 m of the water column) and values are calculated as weighted average.

LTER_EUROPE|03784-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Contains data on plankton organisms derived by microscopy. Bacteria are cell numbers, phytoplankton is biovolume per water volume and zooplankton is fresh mass per volume and taxonomical groups. Data set is incomplete as counting takes much more time.

LTER_EUROPE|03784-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|bacteria: full sample fixed by glutaraldehyde. 20 ml, 0.5 ml prepared for counting, 400 cells counted. algae: full sample fixed by Lugol. 20 ml, 0.2- 1 ml sedimented in a 3 ml chamber. 100 cells counted per dominating species. zooplankton: net sdample of 5 l concnetrated within 100 ml. counted for large species and stages. full sample of 1 l concentrated by sedimentation within 100 ml. 10 ml - all counted.

LTER_EUROPE|03786-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03786-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|In 2011 and 2012, 3101 respectively 3125 trees were evaluated according with ICP Forest Manual in Bucegi - Piatra Craiului LTER site. For most species, the most suitable time for the assessment is mid- to late summer. Defoliation is defined as needle/leaf loss in the assessable crown as compared to a reference tree. Defoliation is assessed in 5% steps. These classes are 0, 5 ( more than0-5%), 10 ( more than5-10%) and so on. The uploaded data presents values in accordance with these criteria.

LTER_EUROPE|03787-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|IT_SI001243_Gulf of Trieste_15052013_Salinity
LTER_EUROPE|03787-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Italy
LTER_EUROPE|03787-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-05-16
LTER_EUROPE|03787-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03787-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Vertical profiles of salinity are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1), using a CTD multiparametric probe. The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Data are used to characterize the temporal dynamic of hydrological properties in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|Diversity, biomass and observed data of grasslands in Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER)
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/givenName|Miklós
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Kertész

LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/individualName/givenName|Gábor
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/individualName/surName|Ónodi
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/organizationName|aaa LTER
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/electronicMailAddress|onodi.gabor@okologia.mta.hu
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-11-19
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The dataset contains number of plant species, diversity (within habitat), number (and type) of layers, presence/absence (and type) of management, presence/absence (and type) of natural disturbances, aboveground biomass by indirect methods, presence/absence of groundwater table and presence/absence of susceptibility of the site to drought. Sampling plots are the same used for biomass and LAI measurements in the Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER) grassland. The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/keywordSet/keyword|land use
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/keywordSet/keyword|droughts
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/keywordSet/keyword|biodiversity

LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/contact/individualName/givenName|Miklós
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/contact/individualName/surName|Kertész
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/contact/organizationName|MTA Centre for Ecological Research
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/contact/electronicMailAddress|kertesz.miklos@okologia.mta.hu
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Number of plant species: The aboveground biomass of vascular plants are removed from 0.5 x 0.5 m quadrats for biomass and LAI measurements. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight. After drying, the photosynthesizing vascular plant material seemingly living at time of cutting (i.e. the dry green material) are separated by species. The species samples are weighed separately at precision of 0.01 grams, the number of species counted. Within habitat diversity: Shannon'H is calculated from vascular plant species dried living biomass data. For one quadrat: m(i) is mass of i-th species, M is total mass, n is number of species, Shannon's H = -SUM(i=1 to n)[(m(i)/M)*log2(m(i)/M)] Number and type of layers: Visual observation. Presence and type of management: Visual observation. Presence of natural disturbances: Visual observation. Aboveground biomass by indirect methods: Spectroradiometry using CROPCSAN spectroradiometer before sampling for BIOMASS. Aboveground plant biomass measurement, see above. Calculation of NDVI for each measurements: (NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED); Application of linear regression between BIOMASS and NDVI data measured in the same quadrats. Presence of groundwater table: Expert decision. Quality of drought susceptibility: Expert decision.
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset, the full biomass and LAI data are submitted in HU_SI001199_biomass_lai_20130508 dataset.
LTER_EUROPE|03790-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription|annually

LTER_EUROPE|03791-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples for SRP analysis were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed spectrophotometrically according to Valderrama (1977).

LTER_EUROPE|03791-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory, where soluble reactive phosphorus was determined spectrophotometrically following the method proposed by Valderrama (1977). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03792-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The soil of the site was classified in JAKUCS, P. (1985): Ecology of an oak forest in Hungary. Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest, pp. 19–32. The original Hungarian classification was transormed to FAO WRB. Soil samples were analysed by an accredited agrochemical laboratory according to standard Hungarian procedures. The following parameters were measured: pH(H2O), soluble salts, upper plasticity limit, calcium-carbonate, humus, total phosporus, total inorganic nitrogen, K2O, C%, N%, C/N.

LTER_EUROPE|03793-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Absorbed fraction of incoming PPFD was assessed indirectly by comparing PPFDs above and below the forest canopy.
LTER_EUROPE|03793-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Hobo Microstations with PPFD sensors (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA)
LTER_EUROPE|03793-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|1-1 PPFD sensor was set above (25m, top of the meteorological tower) and below the forest canopy (2m height, 10m from the meteorological tower), respectively, both within the 'B' subplot of the 1 ha permanent plot of the LTER site. PPFD data were recorded with 10 min sampling frequency and transormed to daily sums. Radiation absorption was assessed by comparing monthly mean PPFDs above and below the canopy layer.

LTER_EUROPE|03794-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, - 16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory, where pH was measured by means of a pH meter. Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03797-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Data set contains characteristics of suspended particulate matter of the Zingster Strom water column (upper 50 cm). This part of the site Darß-Zingst Bodden is situated between the innermost waterbodies and exhibits average salinity and nutrients. Data are sampled daily at 8:00. Data are given as monthly medians. The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

LTER_EUROPE|03797-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range.
LTER_EUROPE|03797-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|seston (suspended particulate matter): filtered onto GFF, dried overnight at 60°C, weightedchlorophyll a: filtered onto GFF, stored frozen, extracted at room temperature in the dark for 16-24 h in ethanol, photometricallyTN and TP: digested with Oxisolv (persulfate) in a lab microwave, neutralised and measured as nitrate and phosphate
LTER_EUROPE|03797-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column daily at 08:00 CET. TN, TP, POC are sampled only weekly. The sampling spot represents a very small spot of the area. However, the Zingster Strom is subject to in- and outflows of the neigbouring bodden basins. This brings a high variability of day-to-day data, but may expand the areal coverage/representation.

LTER_EUROPE|03798-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|ammonium: indophenolblue formation, photometrically, fresh 0,45 mm filtrate, manuallyphosphate: molybdenum blue, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrite: formazan dye, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrate: formazan dye, reduction at a cadmium catalyser, photometrically as nitrite and nitrate, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analyser, corrected for nitrite
LTER_EUROPE|03798-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column daily at 08:00 CET. 100 ml are filtered immediately through 0,45 µm cellulose acetate filters. Ammonium is incubated at once, the other sample is frozen for the 3 other nutrients. The sampling spot represents a very small spot of the area. However, the Zingster Strom is subject to in- and outflows of the neigbouring bodden basins. This brings a high variability of day-to-day data, but may expand the areal coverage/representation.

LTER_EUROPE|03799-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides ammonium concentrations measured in Lake Santo Parmense in 2012. Water samples were collected by means of a Ruttner bottle at different depths over the whole water column at the point of maximum depth of the lake. Samples were analysed spectrophotometrically according to Koroleff (1970).

LTER_EUROPE|03799-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, -16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory where ammonia was determined spectrophotometrically following the Indophenol method described by Koroleff (1970). Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03804-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range.
LTER_EUROPE|03804-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|seston (suspended particulate matter): filtered onto GFF, dried overnight at 60°C, weightedchlorophyll a: filtered onto GFF, stored frozen, extracted at room temperature in the dark for 16-24 h in ethanol, photometricallyTN and TP: digested with Oxisolv (persulfate) in a lab microwave, neutralised and measured as nitrate and phosphate
LTER_EUROPE|03804-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column during monthly boat trips. Samples are transported cooled and in shadow. They are treated within 6 h the same day. The sampling spots represent a very small spot of the area. Mixing evens are just investigated to conclude on representative spots.

LTER_EUROPE|03805-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Data set contains abiotic parameters of the Darß-Zingst Bodden Chain water column (upper 50 cm). 9 sites are sampled along a salinity (1-14 psu) and eutrophication gradient during monthly boat trips. All data are individual results.  The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

LTER_EUROPE|03805-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students paractical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range.
LTER_EUROPE|03805-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|salinity: WTW Cond 1970iwater temperature: mercury thermometerSecchi diskturbidity: Xion 500 photmeter, 5 cm cell lengthpH: Hach-Lange IntelliCell, HQ30doxygen: Hach-Lange LDO optode, HQ30d
LTER_EUROPE|03805-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water column during monthly boat trips. Samples are transported in PE contained as cool as possible, in the shadow. All sampels are treated on the same day (mostly within 6 h). The sampling spots represent most likely the respective water body. However, newest measurements of mixing fronts point to incomplete mixing with the water basins and homgeneously mixed water within the strems and at the connection to the open Baltic.
LTER_EUROPE|03805-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription|monthly

LTER_EUROPE|03806-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Data set contains nutrients of9 stations from the Darß-Zingst Bodden Chain along a salinity and eutrophication gradient in the water column (upper 50 cm). Samples are taken during monthly boat trips. Data are individual values. The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5).

LTER_EUROPE|03806-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The given site contains some of the used methods as laboratory instructions to be downloaded as pdf. They were written for students practical courses. The language of this material is German (only, so far). A station methods manual is under construction. Language will be English. Note, that nutrients are measured in a continuous flow analyser, not manually. Some methods are still missing (plankton microscopy). Some methods changed recently or will be modified soon. Any user has to ask for the exact information for a specific method and time range.
LTER_EUROPE|03806-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|ammonium: indophenolblue formation, photometrically, fresh 0,45 mm filtrate, manuallyphosphate: molybdenum blue, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrite: formazan dye, photometrically, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analysernitrate: formazan dye, reduction at a cadmium catalyser, photometrically as nitrite and nitrate, frozen 0,45 µm filtrate, continuous flow analyser, corrected for nitrite
LTER_EUROPE|03806-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water is sampled with a Rutner sampler from the upper 50 cm of the water during monthly boat trips. Samples are transported in PE containers, cool and shaded. Sampels are treted the same daily (mostly within 6 h). 100 ml are filtered immediately through 0,45 µm cellulose acetate filters. Ammonium is incubated at once, the other sample is frozen for the 3 other nutrients. The sampling spots represent a very small spot of the respective water basins. Water mixing is investigated now.
LTER_EUROPE|03806-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription|monthly

LTER_EUROPE|03807-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Data set contains weather data of Zingst. Data are sampled daily at 8:00. Data are given as monthly medians. The data of 2011 and 2012 are contributed to the EnvEurope project (action 5). Solar radiation, wind speed and direction are available, but are not ready yet (calculation from continuous measurements not ready).

LTER_EUROPE|03807-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|solar radiation: pyranometer CM 11 (Kipp and Zonen, Delft), every 10 min for 30 sec averagedpecipiation sampled every 24 hwind speed: measured every 10 min for 30 s with an anemometer-compact of THIES CLIMA with a measurement range of 0.5 to 50 m s-1 and a sensitivity of ± 0.5 m s-1 at 10 m above ground 
LTER_EUROPE|03807-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Precipitation is sampled daily. Snow is included. Radiation and wind are measured every 10 min. Analog signals are converted by AD changers. Data are recorded in LabView and exported as monthly text files.

LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|Diversity and abundance of birds at TERENO sites (2001): Friedeburg, Greifenhagen, Schafstaedt, Wanzleben

LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/address/country|Germany
LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/phone|+49 3455585304

LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/electronicMailAddress|mark.frenzel@ufz.de
LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/organizationName|aaa LTER
LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-06-13
LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers bird count data of 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. All singing, calling and seen birds were registered according to the point counts method described by Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London.
LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/keywordSet/keyword|Species list

LTER_EUROPE|03813-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Spatial design: 5 quadrats of 1km² arranged as checkerboard grid (4 visiting points in each quadrat, 20 visiting points for each site, 500m distance between each points); each point was visited 3 times (April, May, June) and all singing, calling or seen birds were registered within two circular bands of 50m and 250m radius: the maximum value for each species is considered for evaluation, as same individuals may have been registered more than once at the different times. Reference: Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London

LTER_EUROPE|03814-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03814-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers bird count data of 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. All singing, calling and seen birds were registered according to the point counts method described by Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London.

LTER_EUROPE|03815-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Total Chlorophyll concentration of Lake Candia (Northern Italy), collected by CNR Institute of Ecosystem Study. This parameter is collected from 1986 until now at different depth (surface, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 m depth), and like an integrated water sample from 0 to 6 meters. The concentration is calculated according to the fluorimetric analysis and methanol extraction.

These water samples are filtered, on filters GF/C 47 mm, and placed at 4 ° C until the analysis to the fluorimeter.

LTER_EUROPE|03816-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|This meteorological data are organised in three separate files. First one provides monthly precipitation and mean temperature from both meteorological stations (WMO compatible) placed in Bucegi-Piatra Craiului LTER site, the second one presents daily global radiation reaching the site, and the third one contains other main meteorological variables (wind speedanddirection, relative humidity).

LTER_EUROPE|03817-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|Salinity-Gulf of Trieste time-series_2012
LTER_EUROPE|03817-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Italy
LTER_EUROPE|03817-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-05-16
LTER_EUROPE|03817-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03817-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Vertical profiles of salinty are collected on a monthly basis in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1), using a CTD multiparametric probe. The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Data are used to characterize the temporal dynamic of hydrological properties in the coastal Long Term Ecosystem Research station of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03818-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Discrete water samples for dissolved oxygen analysis were collected at 0.5, 5, 10 and 15 meters in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site. Dissolved oxygen is measured by potentiometric titration. General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03820-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03820-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers bird count data of 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. All singing, calling and seen birds were registered according to the point counts method described by Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London.

LTER_EUROPE|03820-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Spatial design: 5 quadrats of 1km² arranged as checkerboard grid (4 visiting points in each quadrat, 20 visiting points for each site, 500m distance between each points); each point was visited 3 times (April, May, June) and all singing, calling or seen birds were registered within two circular bands of 50m and 250m radius: the maximum value for each species is considered for evaluation, as same individuals may have been registered more than once at the different times. Reference: Bibby et al. (1992): Bird census techniques, Academic press, London
LTER_EUROPE|03820-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Very simple: Binoculars and compass only
LTER_EUROPE|03820-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Sampling took place within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories; http://www.ufz.de/exploratories/index.php?en=21235) platform of the UFZ in saxony-Anhalt (Germany)
LTER_EUROPE|03820-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription|Three times a year: within 1-30 April, 1-20 May, 21 May - 20 June (to be performed each third year)

LTER_EUROPE|03821-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|This dataset includes phytoplankton abundance data taken in two research sites (Lake Cedrino and Temo) of the site Sardinian Lake Ecosystems as part of LTER Italy. Samples were collected as representative of each season during 2012. Data comprise measurements in the water column ad different depth from surface to the bottom.

LTER_EUROPE|03821-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Phytoplankton samples (100 ml) were fixed in Lugol’s solution and analyzed with Utermöhl’s technique (1958). Cell density was valuated analyzing subsamples of 5-10 ml of the fixed samples with an inverted microscope (Zeiss, Axiovert 10) at 200x and 400x magnifications in an adequate number of fields. Species were determined using traditional phycological determination manuals
LTER_EUROPE|03821-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Inverted microscope Zeiss Axiovert serie
LTER_EUROPE|03821-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Samples were collected at different depth (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10 and sometimes at 15 m depth) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection

LTER_EUROPE|03822-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Algal cells are concentrated by filtering a known volume of water through a membrane filter (47 mm, 5.0 µm pore size). The pigments are extracted from the concentrated algal sample in an aqueous solution of acetone. The chlorophyll a concentration is determined spectrophotometrically by measuring the absorbance (optical density - OD) of the extract at various wavelengths. The resulting absorbance measurements are then applied to a standard equation.
LTER_EUROPE|03822-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|In the point of maximum depth of the lake. Water samples are collected at different depths (surface, 1, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10 and sometimes at 15 m depth) with a Niskin bottle and placed in a dark cooler box and packed in ice at the time of collection

LTER_EUROPE|03826-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Dataset provides soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) concentrations measured in Lake Scuro Parmense in 2012. Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/title|Red Crayfish Consumer Biomass at Doñana LTSER Platform (2012)
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/givenName|Ricardo
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Diaz-Delgado
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/organizationName|Estación Biológica de Doñana-CSIC
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/electronicMailAddress|rdiaz@ebd.csic.es
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/individualName/givenName|Ricardo
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/individualName/surName|Diaz-Delgado
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/organizationName|Estación Biológica de Doñana-CSIC
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/metadataProvider/electronicMailAddress|rdiaz@ebd.csic.es
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/pubDate|2013-03-07
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The method consists in the provision of fishing gear (creels) in homogeneously distributed environments in the sampling station. The number of creels to provide depend on each sampling station. In general, it will have as many creels as possible at a distance of not less than 5 meters between them, with a maximum of five. For the selected stations that relate later, creels are arranged in three groups of three creels each, separate creels in at least five meters and groups in at least 50 meters. Each group of creels is considered one unit of effort.Creels should be type "Shrimp" double death with mesh size of 4 mm., Sailing simple and approximate length of 3 m., 1:1 ratio between the candle and the body of the creel.Be placed on the ground, leaving part of the cod always above the water surface. The ring must be input, however, submerged as possible and at least the mouth must always be below the water surface. This arrangement minimizes the creelential effects on birds swimmers and decreases mortality of amphibians and reptiles caught in them.The review will take place between 12 and 24 hours of operation, and has remained at least one night on business.The provision on the ground will be supported on macoyas own vegetation or wetland or lake shore, using these elements to raise the cod and allow ventilation of creels.The withdrawal of the samples was made ​​by nasa, scoring in each case the crab specimens caught mention of the following parameters: a) total length, b) carapace width (of the first 20 copies),c) carapace length (of the first 20 copies), d) sex, e) sexual stage (I or II) and f) specific comments. To each creel is measured weight crabs assembly contained therein by the use of a Pesola. When the sample obtained more than 100 copies will bypass the steps a, b, c, d and e in the copies of the creel after the one containing the copy number 100, it being necessary to measure the remaining copies of the creel in which it is located .Log the data on catches of other specimens of any species, even without specific protocol for them.

LTER_EUROPE|03832-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|The method consists in the provision of fishing gear (creels) in homogeneously distributed environments in the sampling station. The number of creels to provide depend on each sampling station. In general, it will have as many creels as possible at a distance of not less than 5 meters between them, with a maximum of five. For the selected stations that relate later, creels are arranged in three groups of three creels each, separate creels in at least five meters and groups in at least 50 meters. Each group of creels is considered one unit of effort.Creels should be type "Shrimp" double death with mesh size of 4 mm., Sailing simple and approximate length of 3 m., 1:1 ratio between the candle and the body of the creel.Be placed on the ground, leaving part of the cod always above the water surface. The ring must be input, however, submerged as possible and at least the mouth must always be below the water surface. This arrangement minimizes the creelential effects on birds swimmers and decreases mortality of amphibians and reptiles caught in them.The review will take place between 12 and 24 hours of operation, and has remained at least one night on business.The provision on the ground will be supported on macoyas own vegetation or wetland or lake shore, using these elements to raise the cod and allow ventilation of creels.The withdrawal of the samples was made ​​by nasa, scoring in each case the crab specimens caught mention of the following parameters: a) total length, b) carapace width (of the first 20 copies),c) carapace length (of the first 20 copies), d) sex, e) sexual stage (I or II) and f) specific comments. To each creel is measured weight crabs assembly contained therein by the use of a Pesola. When the sample obtained more than 100 copies will bypass the steps a, b, c, d and e in the copies of the creel after the one containing the copy number 100, it being necessary to measure the remaining copies of the creel in which it is located .Log the data on catches of other specimens of any species, even without specific protocol for them.

ALLlANCE METHOOS Parameter: Nitrates -Cadmium Application: Sea water System: FUTURA'MF) Range: 48 -161 1 L 3 -10 N03  I -DESCRIPTION OF THE METHOD: The nitrates are reduced into nitrites in a copper/cadmium column. Nitrites react with sulfanilamid in acid conditions to give a diazo compound. With N-(1-Naphthyl) ethylen diamin, it be comes a pink coloured complex. Colorimetric mesures are performed at 520/540 nm. Cadency : 60 to 80 samples 1hour. 11-REAGENTS PREPARATION : R1 Arnmonium chloride solution Ammonium chloride, NH4CI 10 9 Demineralised water, q.s. 1 000 mi Adjust the pH to 8.5 with ammonium hydroxide, NH40H. Dissolve 20 9 sulfamilamid . Meat if necessary. 0.5 9 Complete up to 2000 mi with D.water. Add 1 mi of 8rij¬Conservatían : 1 month at 4°C and protected from Iight. The cadmium-copper column must be used carefully. The system is run on reagents without the column. Once all reagents are pumped in the analytical circuit, the column is introduced in the circuit without introducing an air buble. At the end af the day, the column is first deconnected and the analytical circuit is then washed. Thus, the calumn remains always in the ammonium chloride solution. Standards preparation Solution 1 000 mg 1I N03 Potassium nitrate, KN03 1.63 9 Demineralised water , q.s. 1 000 mi Dissolve 1.63 9 of potassium nitrate in demineralised water. Add 1 mi of chloroform, CHCI3. Dilute up to 1 000 mi with demineralised water. Stabilitv /Conservatíon : 1 month at 4oC and protected from light. Working standard solution : Dilute stock solution in a about 39 gil of Na CI solution or in sea-water without NH4. Made standards according to the range. Sampler solution : NaCI about 39 gil solution I -DESCRIPTION OF THE METHOD: The ammonium molybdate reacts with the orthophosphates in acid condition to form the phosphomolybdic acid. It is reduced in "molybdene blue" by ascorbic acid. The reaction is catalysed by potassium antimony oxide tartrate. Optical density is measured at the wavelength of 880 nm. -REAGENTS COMPOSITION : Sulfuric acid, about 6 N Sulfuric acid concentrated 95-97 %, H2S04 85 mi O.water, q.s. 500 mi Oissolve 85 mi of concentrated sulfuri9 cid in 200 mi O.water. Cool, adjust to 500 mi with O.water. Ammonium hepta olybdate 4 % Ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate, (NH4)6 M07 024, 4H20 8 9 O.water, q.s. 200 mi Stabilitv I Conservation : about 3 weeks at 4°C in an amber plastic container. LTER_EUROPE|03834-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|To achieve the objectives of this monitoring themselves used traps using light mesh Anguilera shrimp and, in order to obtain a wider range of size in fish catches.Are placed pots anguileras 2 to 5 depending on the dimensions of the station, the technical criterion and if the depth of the station permits, since by design require between 20 and 30 cm minimum depth for proper installation . Pots are preferably installed with a minimum of 15 meters apart. The deaths of pots point to the shore, and in the streams and creeks with current input to death is oriented counter to facilitate the entry of fish. It must ensure that traps are not completely sunk in the water to prevent drowning of other wildlife that can get caught in the trap.Also placed five shrimp pots of light, near-shore and far between around 10 meters, with the deaths to the center of the lagoon, from ingress completely covered by water.After about 24 hours, their extraction, pouring its contents into bowls or baskets with water, which is separated from the individuals counting them and weighing them by species.

LTER_EUROPE|03835-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Canopy trees were assessed in the LTER permanent core hectare in 2012. Abundance was assessed in the whole hectare using tree inventory of the LTER site. Canopy projection of trees was measured according to the ICP forest manual in the 50x50m subplot of the LTER core hectare (subplot 'A'). Shrub layer was assessed in the 50x50m subplot of the LTER core hectare (subplot 'A'), divided into 144 4x4m quadrates. Coverage was measured in 2007. Abundance was measured in 2012. Data on low (1m height) shrubs were processed separately. Herb layer was assessed in the 50x50m subplot of the LTER core hectare (subplot 'A'), divided into 144 4x4m quadrates.
LTER_EUROPE|03835-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|no instruments were used
LTER_EUROPE|03835-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|All vegetation assessments were done in the permanent representative hectare of Sikfokut LTER site which has been used since 1972 for similar purposes. Canopy trees were assessed by Ilona Mészáros and Viktor Oláh. Data on shrub layer was provided by Imre Kárász and Tamás Misik. Data on herb layer was provided by Mária Papp.

LTER_EUROPE|03836-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Annual vascular plant percent cover measured per species along 3 15m long transects inside 15x15m2 plots. 21 plots are placed in the dominant shrubland communities in Doñana Biological Reserve inside the Doñana LTSER Platform. Abundance may directly be estimated from percent cover. Species list is indicated listcode field.

LTER_EUROPE|03837-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|Ammonium concentrations are provided from 10 depths (0 to 70 m)  from the LTER- Marechiara Station in the Gulf of Naples on 4 seasons, 2012. The four data were chosen as to represent differen phases in the seasonal cycle of plankton in the Gulf of Naples

LTER_EUROPE|03839-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03839-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The aim of the yearly biomass measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The total aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data  are submitted in HU_SI001199_lai_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03839-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Biomass in grasslands was measured by harvesting all herbs and plant material over a small parcel of 0.25 m2. In mown grassland, sampling was made right before mowing. Otherwise, the sampling was made approx.at the time of the maximum LAI. As much as possible, clipping was made right at the level of the ground. All plant material was dried at 60⁰C until constant weight.From the dried material three fractions were separated: (1) plant material which was dead in the time of clipping, (2) non-photosynthesising living material, and (3) photosynthesising material.Biomass species was calculated by summing up the dry weight of all living material belong to a species, and expressed in grams / m2.
LTER_EUROPE|03839-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03840-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The dataset contains the EUNIS habitat types of the sampling plots of the Orgovány LTER (KISKUN LTER) grassland biomass and LAI measurements. The aim of the yearly biomass and LAI measurements in the grasslands is to study the effect of weather to the plant production along a productivity gradient. Aboveground living plant biomass data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The total aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data  are submitted in HU_SI001199_lai_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the abovegroung biomass data of plant species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03840-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|The sample were taken in grasslands of Orgovány LTER site of KISKUN LTER. The data are considered to be representative for the grasslands of KISKUN LTER. Aboveground living plant biomass and LAI data from 24-30 grassland patches in Orgovány region of Kiskunság (Kiskunság National Park) along a productivity gradient from open sand grassland to reedbed, yearly from 2003 to 2012, were sampled approx. at the time of maximum aboveground biomass. The size of the patches are 20 to 50 sq-m, and each year one 0.5 by 0.5 m sampling unit is selected within each patch. The patches are permanent ones; some of them were omitted and replaced because of disturbance in several years. The aboveground living plant biomass data of separate species are submitted in HU_SI001199_species_biomass_20130508 dataset, and the EUNIS habitat types of the sampled patches are submitted in HU_SI001199_eunis_habitat_type_20130508 dataset.

LTER_EUROPE|03842-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Counting of apparently occupied nests (AON) in tree nesting colonies is performed during the reproduction season by walking through the entire colony. An AON is a nest that is in use and sufficiently finished to hold one or more eggs of a breeding pair (BP). Counts are made when the maximum numbers of nests are occupied. If the nests were counted several times within the same season, the maximum number was considered.

LTER_EUROPE|03843-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|These data are seven freshwater parameters of Srebarna Lake. They are: water depth (m) of the lake, pH, conductivity, transperance Secchi (m), the amount of NO2, the amount of PO4 (mg/l) and the amount of Chlorophil a (mg/l). They were taken in May, August and November 2012 and these are data for spring, summer and winter season.

LTER_EUROPE|03847-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The data are for 2 lakes in Danube Delta SI000709: Rosu ( 45° 3'14.80"N 29°34'30.84"E) and Baclanesti ( 45°14'53.86"N 29° 7'44.22"E). Monthly data from 1975 to 1994 for Rosu and from 1982 to 1993 for Baclanesti. The lakes are tipical shallow floodplain lakes, their level being highly dependent of the Danube discharge. Variable list: CP,Deptht, NH4N, NO3N, Ntot, O2D, pH, PO4, Ptot, S_org, SDT, SI, Temp (water).

This allow higher visibility (sunlight coming from the back). Stops were made when necessary (counting or identification). Wind speed (6 categories from calm to gale), wind direction, sky conditions (6 categories from sunny to rainy), sea conditions (6 categories from calm to very rough) and human use of the beach were noted together with bird counts
