LTER_EUROPE|03853-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Litterfall collection by litter traps. Destructive sampling for aboveground biomass estimations of Q. petraea, Q. cerris and Acer campestre. Direct measurement of cut trees and separation of stem, branch and leaf biomasses. Allometry equations and tree inventory data (DBH) for estimation of total aboveground biomass of Quercus species.
LTER_EUROPE|03853-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Litter traps for litter production. Destructive harvesting of trees for biomass measurements.
LTER_EUROPE|03853-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Litterfall was assessed in 2012 using 25 litter traps representing the permanent hectare of the site, with 5.11 m2 total area and was transformed to kg/ha. Destructive samplings (3-3 individuals of Q. petraea, Q. cerris, Acer campestre) were performed within the LTER site, ~300 m from the 1 ha permanent plot. Tree inventory (DBH) of the 1 ha permanent plot was used for estimating aboveground biomass of Q. petraea and Q. cerris tree-by-tree and was summed up to kg/ha.

LTER_EUROPE|03855-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/language|eng
LTER_EUROPE|03855-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net).  TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers data about bees trapped within 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. The trapping is done with combined flight traps (combination of yellow pan trap and transparent perspexes) placed at ecotones (transition zone between arable fields and semi-natural habitats) in May-June and August-September each year.

LTER_EUROPE|03855-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|One trap / km² is placed at the border (ecotone) between semi-natural habitat and arable field (16 traps / site of 4x4 km). Traps consist of a yellow funnel (diameter: 25 cm) and two crossed perspex windows on top of the funnel. Trapped insects will fall in the funnel which is filled with water containing a preservative (Parmetol K 40; 0.5%). Traps are installed with a wooden frame at a height of about one m above ground. Operating schedule (emptying interval 14 days): Start at week 2–7 after full bloom of Taraxacum officinale (phenological indicator), usually in our region end of April or beginning of May; 4x emptying until end of June, then stop for 6 weeks and start again until end of September. Insects are sorted in the laboratory and sent to a specialist for determination. Frequency: yearly
LTER_EUROPE|03855-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Yellow funnels, perspexes and wooden frames (trap material needs to be organized individually)

LTER_EUROPE|03857-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|LAI was assessed by indirect optical method using LAI-2000 instrument. Crown transparency and defoliation was assessed only for Q. petraea and Q. cerris trees according to the ICP Forest Manual. Stand-level mean starting and finishing days of leaf expansion and leaf shedding were determined indirectly by above- and below-canopy positioned PPFD sensors.
LTER_EUROPE|03857-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|LAI measuements: LiCor LAI-2000 intrument. Crown health status: visual observation, ICP Forest manual. Leaf expansion and leaf shedding: Hobo Micro Station with PPFD sensor (Onset Computer Corporation, Pocasset, USA)
LTER_EUROPE|03857-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|LAI-measurement was done along 10x10m sampling grid in the LTER site's 1 ha permanent plot in August 2012. As a total 81 sampling points were used, each measured in triplicate. All measurements were averaged to calculate mean LAI in 2012. Crown transparency and defoliation were assessed according to the ICP Forest Manual for all Quercus petraea and Q. cerris trees in the 'A' subplot (50x50m) of the LTER site's 1 ha permanent plot. Tree-by-tree assesment was done for all Q. petraea (59 ind.) and Q. cerris (13 ind.) trees of the subplot. Starting and finishing days of leaf exansion and leaf sheding were determined comparing daily sum of above- and below-canopy PPFD. Above-canopy PPFD was measured on the top of the site's own meteorological tower at 25m. Below-canopy PPFD sensor was set ~10m from the meteorological tower at 2m. Both sensors was set to 10 min sampling interval. For characterizing actual canopy status mean PPFDbelow/PPFDabove between DOYs 0-70 was considered as 'no canopy' status and PPFDbelow/PPFDabove between DOYs 150-250 was considered as 'full canopy' status. Reaching one of the above values was considered as starting or finishing of leaf exansion or leaf sheding, respectively.

LTER_EUROPE|03862-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|This dataset provides data about annual net primary production in the Síkfőkút LTER site (Hungary). Annual dry mass increment of canopy Quercus petraea and Q. cerris trees in 2011 and 2012 was assessed by tree ring and allometry data and corrected with tree mortality. Total litterfall in 2012 provides information on renewable biomass flux.

LTER_EUROPE|03862-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Analysis of annual tree increment by tree rings and calculation of dry weight change by allometry equations. Assessment of total litter production by litter traps.
LTER_EUROPE|03862-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Tree rings: increment borer, digital scanner, ImageJ image analyses software. Litterfall: litter traps.
LTER_EUROPE|03862-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Stand-level biomass increment was assessed by tree ring analyses. In 2011 130 Q. petraea and 99 Q. cerris samples were analyzed. In 2012 19-19 Q. petraea and Q. cerris samples were analyzed. All samples were collected in the permanent 1 hectare plot of the LTER site. Mean tree ring widths were used in allometry equations to calculate aboveground biomass change tree-by-tree and sum up to stand level using tree inventory of the site. Yearly increments were corrected by tree mortality data. Litterfall was assessed in 2012 using 25 litter traps representing the permanent hectare of the site, with 5.11 m2 total area and transformed to kg/ha.

LTER_EUROPE|03869-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/ulink/@url|http://www-rbd.ebd.csic.es/Seguimiento/mediobiologico/vegetacionacuatica/ProtocoloFenologiaVegetacionAcuatica.pdf
LTER_EUROPE|03869-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Every water body is sampled during 15' starting from the shore to the deepest point. Macrophyte species are recorded and relative abundance is de visu assigned according to the following criteria:1 Species present in the sample by just one individual2 Percent cover less than 5%3 Percent cover more than5% and 25% and 50%Sampling period strictly depends on presence of water in the water bodies and is selected according to vegetative activity. Usually this corresponds to 2 seasonal samplings.

LTER_EUROPE|03870-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|The data set provides information about the relationship between abiotic and biotic environments on the ecosystem scale whereas the extensity is correlated by the intensity of effective factors of structural and functional change. Available data comprise element cycling and water relationships on the one hand and the dynamics of effective concentrations mainly in the soil solution. Supplementary data are values for characterizing ecosystem structures and the related element pools as well as climate.

LTER_EUROPE|03871-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para|This dataset contains the vascular plant species list of Sikfokut LTER site (Hungary).The list was composed of the results of a Multisite Experiment in 2007 and 2008, tree and shrub inventory in 2012, and herb layer assessment in 2012, respectively.Tree layer was assessed by Mészáros Ilona.Shrub layer was assessed by Misik Tamás and Kárász Imre.Herb layer was assessed by Papp Mária.

LTER_EUROPE|03871-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Vascular plants' species list was composed using results of a Multisite Experiment (MSE) in summer in 2007 and 2008, and tree and shrub inventory of the site's 1 ha permanent plot in 2012, respectively. Herb layer was assessed using 20 0.5x2m rectangular plots.
LTER_EUROPE|03871-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/instrumentation|Permanent vegetation plots.
LTER_EUROPE|03871-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Most vegetation assessments were done in the 1 ha permanent plot of Sikfokut LTER site which has been used since 1972 for similar purposes. Canopy trees were assessed by Ilona Mészáros and Viktor Oláh. Data on shrub layer was provided by Imre Kárász and Tamás Misik. Data on herb layer was provided by Mária Papp. Further species were added to the list according to the species list composed during a Multisite Experiment in 2007-2008. This experiment was conducted within the borders of the site, ~300 m from the permanent 1 ha plot and used 20 0.5x1m plots.

LTER_EUROPE|03875-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout|Samples are digested in an autoclave for 30 minutes at 121 °C with ammonium persulfate and sulfuric acid to convert all phosphorus to orthophosphate. The orthophosphate is then analyzed using the ascorbic acid procedure.

LTER_EUROPE|03876-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|Water samples were collected at the point of maximum depth of the lake by means of a Ruttner bottle. Samples were collected at the following depths: 0, -1 m, -2 m, -4 m, -6 m, -8 m, -12 m, - 16 m, bottom. Samples were kept refrigerated and transported to the laboratory, where conductivity was measured by means of a conductivity meter. Samples were collected monthly from May to October 2012.

LTER_EUROPE|03877-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/creator/individualName/surName|Italy

LTER_EUROPE|03877-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/abstract/section/para| Discrete water samples for chlorophyll-a analysis were collected at 0.5, 5, 10 and 15 meters in the Gulf of Trieste – time series station (station C1). The site is part of the LTER-North Adriatic site.The overall aim of Long Term Ecosystem Research in the coastal area of the Gulf of Trieste, in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea and of the Mediterranean basin is to gain a better understanding of the temporal dynamics of phytoplankton bloom evolution, with particular focus on the response to natural and man – induced environmental changes.General information can be found at: http://nettuno.ogs.trieste.it/ilter/BIO/index.html

LTER_EUROPE|03877-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/methodStep/description/section/para/literalLayout| Fluorimetric determination after particulate sample concentration by vacuum filtration and extraction in 90% acetone according to Holm – Hansen et al. (1965) and Lorenzen and Jeffrey (1980). Samples were filtered on Whatmann GF/F filters (diameter 47 mm, nominal porosity 0.7 μm) which were stored frozen (-20°C) until laboratory analysis. In order to assess precision and accuracy of measurements, on a regular basis, analytical and field precision measurements are carried out, based on the analysis of replicate samples and, with the aim of testing the accuracy, the laboratory participates to international intercalibration tests (QUASIMEME).
LTER_EUROPE|03877-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/studyExtent/description/section/para|The time series station C1 ( Latitude 45°42'2.99"N Longitude 13°42'36.00"E), located in the Gulf of Trieste in the northernmost part of the Adriatic Sea, is part of the Adriatic Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) site . It is a shallow coastal station (17 m depth) located at 0.2 Km from the coast, at the outer border of the Natural Marine Reserve of Miramare , Trieste.
LTER_EUROPE|03877-metadata.xml|/ns0:eml/dataset/methods/sampling/samplingDescription|continual
